title: Torricelliâ€™s Trumpet: A Story of Pride, Mathematics, and Infinity
author: Swarnim Verma
content:
On the planet** Demood**, a world governed by the immutable laws of mathematical magic, reigned a King with a singular, awesome power: control over time itself. He could **propel his world into the future** with a mere thought, though a limitation haunted his omnipotenceâ€Šâ€”â€Šhe could **never returnÂ back**.

One day, a silent vessel descended, bearing **an alien named Torricelli**. He presented the King with a curious object: **a trumpet of impossible dimensions**. It began with a wide opening but tapered away into an infinitely long, infinitely thinÂ horn.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/824/1*ZzrF_jljEqdTmZ_TXW1ZpQ.png)
Torricelli â€˜sÂ Trumpet**Torricelli **made a simple, yet profound request: that his trumpet be coated in **Demoodâ€™s** most prized substance, the** â€œRoyal Water of Logic.â€** To the King, this was no mere requestÂ , it was a challenge to his dominion over the physical world. His pride stirred, but caution bade him first consult the sharpest minds on theÂ planet.

The **Grand Geometer** approached the throne after careful deliberation. â€œMy Lord,â€ he began, â€œthis bizarre shape is a physical representation of the function **y = 1/x, rotated 360 degrees about the x-axis, from x = 1 to infinity.**â€


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/1*-LQAAACRUqBX3quM3SmI_A.png)
graph of y =Â 1/xHe continued, explaining that on** Demood**,** where atoms were theoretical points, the Royal Water could flow into the most infinitesimal of spaces.** The mathematician then presented his calculations for the trumpetâ€™s volume.

The volume is given by the integral as in the figure below. When we solve this, **we get a finite, almost trivialÂ amount**.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/1*ijDu_gBbkRDXgaT_7s63gQ.jpeg)
Intuition behind the formula used to calculate volume
![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/949/1*i9NOgc9SKBHfdtI8BfoUBw.png)
Total volume enclosed byÂ trumpet**â€œA volume of exactly Ï€ cubic units!â€ **the mathematician chuckled. **â€œMy Lord, not only can we coat this trumpet, we can fill it from the inside and gift the water to theÂ alien!â€**

Bolstered by this finite answer, the Kingâ€™s ego swelled. He accepted the challenge. First, to demonstrate his power, he decided to fill the trumpet. With a flick of his wrist and a whisper of enchanted words, time elapsed, and the trumpet was filled with precisely Ï€ cubic units of the Royal Water. Torricelli watched, impassive.

Now for the main task: coating the infinite exterior. In his haste and supreme confidence, the King uttered the enchanting words to coat the surface, but in his hubris, he forgot a crucial parameter: **the thickness of the coating. The magic interpreted the command as coating an infinite surface with a finite thickness â€˜tâ€™ ( though â€˜tâ€™ was as small as you can think of but notÂ zero).**

A silent, terrifying vortex erupted from the trumpet. The Royal Water of Logic, the lifeblood of **Demood**, was ripped from its lakes, its rivers, even the very cells of its flora and fauna. In a horrifying instant, the vibrant world was desiccated. The lush planet became a barren, grey sphere of dust. **The King watched in shock as his beautiful kingdom vanished, consumed by hisÂ command.**

He stood alone on the barren land, a terrible thirst gripping him. Parched and in despair, he remembered the finite water trapped *within* the trumpet. As he tipped the trumpet to pour the final, precious drop,** his eyes caught the formula for the surface area,** hidden within the trumpet itselfâ€Šâ€”â€Ša detail no one had warned him about, and one he had never thought to question.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/646/1*NPznF-D1ylPTl-Cf6VyzdQ.png)
Total surface area of trumpet (interior or exterior) is notÂ finite
![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/1*0Dp1sOzwMJrDe3t7zJZ5Qw.jpeg)
Intuition behind formula used to calculate surfaceÂ areaIn that moment, the King understood the terrible truth. He had filled a **finite volume** of water inside the trumpet, but the **surface he tried to coat was infinite**. No matter how much he poured, **the interior coatingâ€™s thickness decreased as x grew larger, approaching zero at infinity**. The inside of the trumpet was covered automatically as it filled, but the outside surface demanded an **infinite amount of water**( he could have coated the exterior if he decreased the coating thickness as x increases).

The King was left with nothing but a dry planet and a dreadful new knowledge. One has to wonder: How many more trumpets did Torricelli carry? How many other worlds, ruled by pride, did he visit? Was Demood a victim of Torricelliâ€™s cunning or the Kingâ€™s foolishness? Or perhaps, in the end, a planet whose very nameâ€Šâ€”â€Š**Demood**â€Šâ€”â€Šis **Doomed** spelled in reverse was simply fulfilling itsÂ destiny.

## Ponder a bitÂ :
Why did we approximate a small portion of Gabrielâ€™s Horn (trumpet) as a **cylinder** when calculating volume, but as a **frustum of a cone** when calculating surfaceÂ area?*Hint:* For volume, the contribution of a thin slice depends mainly on its **cross-sectional area**, so treating it as a cylinder is sufficient. For surface area, the **slant or tilt of the surface** matters, so a frustum better approximates the curved geometry. (Rigorous proofs are available online)Is it possible to construct a smooth surface, similar to Gabrielâ€™s Horn, that has **infinite volume but finite surfaceÂ area?**[Gabrielâ€™s hornâ€Šâ€”â€ŠWikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gabriel%27s_horn#Converse)## ReferencesÂ :

title: A Gentle Introduction To Game Theory
author: Mainak Sarkar
content:
## To Snitch or to Stick Together? A SpartanÂ Dilemma
Imagine you are a Spartan soldier stationed at the border of Thermopylae in 300 BC, alongside your comrade, Krish. The Persian army looms on the horizon, and your commander, Leonidas, has tasked you with guarding the pass. However, the nights are long, and the temptation to rest is strong. You and Krish agree to take turns keeping watch, allowing the other to sleep. But you both know that if the Persians attack while one of you is asleep, the consequences will be dire. The commander has made it clear: if either of you fails in your duty, you will be exiled from the SpartanÂ ranks.

But there is a catchÂ , the commander cannot fire both of you simultaneously as he cannot afford to lose two brave soldiers at once. So, if both of you sleepÂ , the commander will do nothingÂ . So, both of you completely exhausted from the toil of the day decided to sleep this night. But if you sleep and Krish decides to snitch on you then he will get promoted high up the ranks as he chooses to remain true to the commander. So, he will always have the incentive to snitch on you. You cannot completely trust Krish if he will stay true upon your earlier agreement. What should you doÂ now?

The reasoning is asÂ follows:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/862/1*2vT5G009lZfPO2Z_mcVPFQ.png)
If you keep watch and Krish does not, he will be exiled, but you are safe. You may feel sorry for him, but at least you remain a Spartan warrior.
On the other hand, if Krish decides to keep watch, then you should do the same to avoidÂ exile.

But the same reasoning applies to Krish. So, both of you sacrifice your rest and keep watch. Evidently, you would both be better off if you both remained true to your words and took turns resting. But that desirable outcome is not possible! If each of you behaves rationallyâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat is, does what is best for himselfâ€Šâ€”â€Škeeping watch is the only reasonable thing to do. Perhaps next time, when you trust each other more, you can find a better solution.

This is a classic example of a problem of Game Theory known as **Prisonerâ€™s Dilemma** where acting in your own self-interest or non-cooperation leads to a worse outcome for everyone but still itâ€™s the only rational decision. Letâ€™s break it down step by step, define the strategies, construct the payoff matrix, and identify the dominated strategy.

Again, what is **dominated strategy** and **payoff matrices**?
In game theory, a dominated strategy is a strategy that yields a worse outcome for a player regardless of what the other player does. In other words, no matter what strategy the opponent chooses, the player is always better off choosing a different strategy.
A payoff matrix in game theory is like a scoreboard that shows what each player gets depending on the choices they make. Itâ€™s a simple table that helps visualize the outcomes of a game. Here to construct a simple payoff matrix lets denote the outcome of getting exiled as 0,as it is the worst outcome possible, having to keep the watch as 1, as it is better than getting exiled and getting rest as 2 which is the best outcome possible.

Nash Equilibrium:
The Nash Equilibrium occurs when no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy, given the other playerâ€™s strategy. In this case:
If both players choose Keep Watch, neither can improve their payoff by switching toÂ Rest.

a. If you switch to Rest, your payoff drops from 1 to 0.
b. Similarly, if Krish switches to Rest, his payoff drops from 1 toÂ 0.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/239/1*7vSDNd_O34nlaqtbQBY7iQ.png)
Payoff MatrixThus, the Nash Equilibrium is for both players to Keep Watch, even though both would prefer the outcome where both Rest (which is not an equilibrium because itâ€™s unstableâ€Šâ€”â€Šeach player has an incentive to deviate).
The Spartan Dilemma is a clear example of the Prisonerâ€™s Dilemma. The dominated strategy for both players is to Rest, as Keep Watch always yields a higher payoff regardless of the other playerâ€™s choice. The Nash Equilibrium is for both players to Keep Watch, even though mutual cooperation (Rest, Rest) would be preferable. This highlights the tension between individual rationality and collective benefit, a central theme in game theory.
By analyzing this scenario with a payoff matrix and identifying the dominated strategy, we can see how game theory provides a rigorous framework for understanding strategic decision-making in conflict situations, whether on the battlefield or in everydayÂ life.

## Repetitive Games:
The name â€œgame theoryâ€ is misleading. Game theory is mostly not about games (although it can also be applied to games). Rather, game theory considers any interaction among multiple parties with conflicting interests, and uses logical reasoning (and mathematics) to analyse such interactions.
Suppose you are in 480 BCÂ . The Spartans and Persians are at war with each other. Both countries station their armies along the shared border. The armies are positioned next to each other, on opposite sides of the border. As night falls, soldiers from both sides retreat to their barracks, hoping for a peaceful nightâ€™s rest, except for a few soldiers who stay on guard. But then, the Spartan commander Leonidas says to his deputy, â€œI have an idea. Since Persian army is going to sleep, this is our opportunity to strike. With all our forces, we can easily overpower their guards and launch a surprise attack while the rest of their troops are asleep. Wake up all our soldiersâ€Šâ€”â€Šweâ€™re heading to the border!â€
The deputy, wanting to rest, responds, â€œSir, what if Persian army doesnâ€™t sleep? Then we wonâ€™t be able to defeat them.â€ To which Leonidas replies, â€œIn that case, we must go to the border; otherwise, they might strike us first!â€ With this solid rationale, the entire Spartan army moves to the border, prepared for battle.
However, the same logical argument holds for Persian forces. They, too, march toward the border, where both armies inevitably collide in a brutal confrontation. What a senseless waste!
Sadly, this logic seems to apply night after nightâ€¦ so are the two armies destined for endless conflict? Does game theory suggest that constant fighting is the only rational choice?
Fortunately, the answer is no. In fact, advanced game theory analysis shows us the opposite: in such situations, logical reasoning often leads to cooperation, not endless conflict.
How can this be? Is there a flaw in the Leonidas reasoning? Yes and no. His logic is sound if we consider each night as an isolated event. However, when we account for the repeated nature of the conflictâ€Šâ€”â€Šnight after nightâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe logic changes. How so?
Letâ€™s revisit the conversation between Leonidas and his deputy. This time, the deputy says, â€œSir, yesterday while walking along the border, I encountered the deputy of Persian army. He shouted over the fence that they plan to sleep tonight, but he warned me that if we attack, they will retaliate and continue to strike us every night thereafter! I shouted back that the same applies to us.â€
Now, is attacking tonight still the best choice? Probably not. Although an attack might provide a short-term benefit, the long-term consequences of continuous battles night after night would far outweigh the initial gain. This holds true for both sides! Therefore, both armies decide not to attack and instead get some much-needed rest. The same decision is made the following night, and the night after thatâ€¦
It becomes clear that repeated interactions change the situation entirely! While confrontation seemed the logical course in a one-off scenario, cooperation emerges as the most rational strategy when the conflict is ongoing. Game theory teaches us that cooperation is often the most logical approach in repeated situations, even between opposing and hostile parties! According to game theory, cooperation is frequently the best course of actionâ€Šâ€”â€Ševen if you are only concerned with your own benefit.
This idea of cooperation and equivalent retaliation was first introduced by **Robert Axelrodâ€™s seminal work on the concept of â€œtit for tatâ€. **
The idea of â€œtit for tatâ€ isnâ€™t just some game theory conceptâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s a powerful lesson in how people (and even nature) handle cooperation and conflict. You can see it everywhere, from politics to animal behavior, shaping the way societies and relationships work. In todayâ€™s complicated world, this simple strategy reminds us that playing fair and treating others as they treat us can lead to more cooperation, understanding, andÂ respect

title: The Banach-Tarski Paradox
author: Saptarshi Mandal
content:
Banach-Tarski says that it is possible to cut up a solid sphere into pieces that by simple rotations can be rearranged into two identical spheres of the same size as the original. No trickery!

In this article we shall describe the notion of infinity, give an intuitive proof of the Banach-Tarski Paradox, and show how it challenges our definition ofÂ volume.

## Axioms
Using logic to deduce new facts from known facts, is a vital part of mathematics. But, to apply logic, we need a starting pointâ€Šâ€”â€Ša set of facts that we assume to be true, before we deduce new facts fromÂ it.

These are called Axioms. The **Axiom of Choice** is an intuitively â€œobviousâ€ axiom that leads to strange, paradoxical results like the Banach-Tarski Paradox.

The **Axiom of Choice** says that given a collection of non-empty sets, it is possible to construct a new set by choosing one element from each set in the collection.

## **Different Infinities**
Before we start talking about the theorem, it is important to illustrate that infinities come in different sizes. Cantorâ€™s diagonal argument shows that the number of reals is greater than the number of naturals even though there are infinitely-many ofÂ both.

In particular, there are more **real numbers** between 0 and 1 than there are **natural numbers** on the entire number line.
Say we list all infinitely-many **naturals** against the infinitely-many distinct **reals** between 0 and 1, randomly.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/1*1nyAi6rMAvwOOZn-xgDJ_A.png)
Cantorâ€™s diagonalÂ argumentFrom such a listing, we can â€œconstructâ€ a new real number that is not in this list. Simply take the nth decimal entry of this new real number to be different from the n-th entry of the number listed against the n-th naturalÂ number.

So, in this case the number 0.05134953 differs from the 0th -number at the 0th-place, the 1st-number at the 1st-place, etc. Hence, just in between (0, 1) we have more real numbers than we have natural numbers on the entire numberÂ line.

We define the number of naturals to be **â€œcountableâ€-infinite** and the number of reals as **â€œuncountableâ€-infinite**.

## Holes Donâ€™tÂ Matter
Say, we have a unit circle, and name a point as 0. Now, we start walking along the circleâ€™s circumference, in steps of length 1. As the circles circumference is irrational, weâ€™ll never step on an already stepped point. Let us name these points by the number of steps taken to reach them, namely, 1, 2, 3,Â ...


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/575/1*XDrI0rdj1uNC79tBG79TXQ.png)
Now, we delete the point marked 0, and replace it with the point marked 1. We continue by replacing the hole at 1, with the point marked 2 and so on, replacing every n-th point with the (n + 1)-thÂ point.

Since we have infinitely many such labelled points, every hole will be filled, and the circle will be completed. That is, at the end of the process, we will again have the original circle, with no evidence that one point wasÂ removed.

We can do this again, be simply choosing another 0 point. We conclude that when we remove **â€œcountablyâ€-infinite** points from a set of **â€œuncountablyâ€-infinite** points, the number of elements of the new set is same as the number of elements of the originalÂ set.

| uncountable set | = | uncountable set |â€Šâ€”â€Š| countable set|

This idea will be useful in a later part of theÂ proof.

In the following intuitive proof, weâ€™ll only consider cutting and rearranging one hollow sphere into two. The idea for a solid ball isÂ similar.

## Naming points on theÂ sphere
Consider the following two actions on a hollowÂ sphere.

A 180â—¦ rotation about an axis FÂ , denoted by fÂ .

angle to the axisÂ F)

It is easy to see that fÂ² = e and gÂ³ = e, where e is the identity action. (The
identity action is where the sphere remains unchanged)

If we consider the set of all strings formed using f, g in which the sub-strings â€œff â€ and â€œgggâ€ do not occur, we can see that each element of the set corresponds to an unique action on the sphere. Let that setÂ be:

P = {e, f, g, fg, gf, gÂ²f, gfg, fgÂ², fgf,Â .Â .Â .}; The set P is countable.

We shall now construct a paradoxical decomposition: P = I âˆª J âˆª K such that the sets I, J, K, J âˆª K are congruent.

Consider the following â€œmachineâ€ T (function) that takes in an element of P
and gives us a set of elements of P by appending something toÂ it.

The TÂ machineWith the help of the above â€œmachineâ€ we will outline an algorithm. This algorithm helps to break down the set P into disjoint subsets I, J, K with some special properties.

Hence, I, J, K, J âˆª K are congruent.

## Decomposing theÂ sphere
Now, we shall partition the sphere. Let the set of points on the sphere beÂ S.

**Observation**: Whenever we rotate a sphere, there are exactly two points that stay put, namely, theÂ poles.

**Observation**: Each action in PÂ , except the identity, is also a rotation, so for
each action we will have two fixedÂ points.

Let us collect all those countably many fixed points or poles into a setÂ D.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/1*TEBorRdYul2S84KwHwTgVg.png)
The sets S \ D andÂ DTo all the uncountably many points in S \ D, we apply the actions in PÂ . For a
point x, we get P(x) = {x, f x, gx, fgx, gfx, gÂ²f x, gfgx, fgÂ²x, fgf x,Â .Â .Â .}

**Observation**: For any two points, x â‰  y on the sphere, either P(x) = P(y) or
P(x) âˆ© P(y) = âˆ…. So, we get an equivalence relation, that induces a partition on S \Â D.

The equivalence relation used to decompose theÂ sphereNow, we create a set M by picking one element from each partition of S \ D
and putting it in MÂ . It is evident that by applying P to MÂ , we get S \Â D.

Since, we have already decomposed PÂ , and now have a â€œrepresentative setâ€ M that gives S \ D when we apply P to it, we have decomposed S \ D asÂ follows:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/1*-5VeoJYdk4lNEDSIGJ0Dcg.png)

On the pieces that we decomposed the sphere into, we apply the following rotations:

second sphere. But, we have already demonstrated that a sphere and a sphere with D removed are equivalent, using the circleÂ analogy.

This concludes theÂ sketch.

## The Axiom ofÂ Choice
We had to invoke the Axiom of Choice in the creation of the set MÂ . Itâ€™s creation was crucial in decomposing theÂ sphere.

Proofs using the Axiom of Choice are totally non-constructive in nature. That is, we simply are guaranteed an existence of an object, in this case the set MÂ , with no information as to how to createÂ it.

The Banach-Tarski Paradox, hints at the existence of sets inside RÂ³ that challenges our definition of volume. For example, the set I, J, K are congruent, and seemingly should have the same volume. However, on rotating I by 180â—¦Â , we get f(I) which has the same volume as J âˆª K. The volume of set I changes on rotation!

This means we need a much more rigorous definition of â€œvolumeâ€ that does not betray us, like the naive definition does in thisÂ case!

## Simpsonâ€™s ParadoxÂ : The Mirage Of DataÂ Science
## The Great War of Mathematics
Letâ€™s journey back in time to the yearÂ **1711**.

You find yourself in the midst of **The Great War of Mathematics**, a fierce intellectual battle fought between two legendary nemeses: **Isaac Newton** and **Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz**. Donâ€™t worryâ€Šâ€”â€Šyouâ€™re perfectly safe here (no arrows of logic or razor-sharp deductions will harmÂ you).

Both titans wield armies of unimaginable power, consisting of **axioms** and** theorems**, ready to clash for mathematical supremacy. Have you ever wondered what a true battlefield of mathematics might look like? If not, letâ€™s imagine itÂ today!

Since childhood, Iâ€™ve dreamed of having a hypothesis named after me. Guess what? Iâ€™ve concocted this completely nonsensical one hereÂ ğŸ˜….

**With that, I invite you to embark on a journey through my hypothetical world, where math is not just theoryâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™sÂ warfare.**

## The Setup
**Axioms** are like fearless infantry, forming the foundation of theÂ army.**Theorems** are the cavalry, swift and powerful, riding in to secureÂ victory.**Newtonâ€™s** army boasts a formidable force of infantry*** N_i*** and cavalry ***N_c***. Meanwhile, **Leibnizâ€™s** troops are equally valiant, with infantry ***L_i ***and cavalry ***L_c***. Both armies are of the **same total strength**, setting the stage for a balanced confrontation.

The battlefield is set. The war rages on for five long years, filled with intellectual maneuvers, strategic deductions, and relentless battles of wits. But in** 1716**, just as **Leibnizâ€™s** forces seem poised for victory, disaster strikes. The great **Leibniz**â€Šâ€”â€Š*not by logic or a rival theorem, but by a cruel irony*â€Šâ€”â€Š*misplaces his spectacles* and vanishes from the battlefield, leaving his ideas toÂ falter.

Both armies suffer tremendous losses over the course of this great war of ideas. As a renowned mathematician in this hypothetical world, I now turn to the statistics that reveal the true scale of these intellectual casualties. Letâ€™s examine the graph below, where we begin to unravel the mystery behind the staggering losses on bothÂ sides.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/977/0*mzHZ_HGW3bw4D-Uo)
Figure 1## The front that suffered fewer casualties was victorious.
**Which side do you think suffered greater casualties?**

Many of you might assume that Newtonâ€™s side took the brunt of the losses, especially since both his infantry and cavalry suffered a higher percentage of casualties. The evidence seems clearâ€Šâ€”â€ŠNewtonâ€™s forces appeared to be in far worseÂ shape.

**But Newton did notÂ lose!!!!**

This revelation struck me like a thunderclap. I, too, was shaken by the truth of it. Yet, the data does not lie. When I examined the overall statistics, the outcome was irrefutable. Those still skeptical of my words, I invite you to glance through the following graph.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/977/0*NBzvK9hVis7MGEp4)
Figure 2**â€œOverall casualty rate of Newton could be less than that of Leibniz if at least one of the Newtonâ€™s regimentâ€™s casualty rate had been less than that of LeibnizÂ . There was no way that the weighted average of casualty rates could show such contrary results.â€**â€” CommonÂ SenseNow, I ask you to take a moment and reflect on where the anomaly might lie. Why does our common sense seem to betray us? How could Newtonâ€™s side, despite higher casualties in both infantry and cavalry, emerge victorious?

The timing is perfect for a revelation!

Brace yourselfâ€Šâ€”â€Šhereâ€™s the formal definition of **Simpsonâ€™s Paradox**:

## **Simpsonâ€™s paradox is a phenomenon in probability and statistics in which a trend appears in several groups of data but disappears or reverses when the groups are combined.**
While you ponder this, let us dive deeper into the demographics of both armies. Understanding the makeup of ***Newton* **and** *Leibnizâ€™s*** forces may provide the key to unraveling this perplexing paradox.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/977/0*RNBsov83hMFVEEde)

![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/977/0*KAmPM0Y2FGeAMl3y)
Notice the stark difference between the two armies. After examining these pie charts, the entire paradox unraveled before my eyes, reducing itself to nothing more than a simple oversightâ€Šâ€”â€Šconfounding variables. Do you see it? Let meÂ explain.

**Confounding variables* are factors that influence other variables in such a way that they create misleading or distorted associations betweenÂ them.***Earlier, we **failed **to account for a crucial variable: the composition of the army. Once we incorporate the effect of this, the mystery dissolves, and we arrive at a remarkably intuitive explanation for the Simpsonâ€™s Paradox we encountered earlier.

## WAS IT REALLY A PARADOXÂ ?
Although **Newtonâ€™s **infantry suffered a higher casualty rate than **Leibnizâ€™s**, it made up only 20% of **Newtonâ€™s** army. In other words, while nearly all soldiers in **Newtonâ€™s** infantry regiment perished, the regiment itself was relatively small.

In contrast, **Leibnizâ€™s** army had a much larger proportion of infantry, with a significant casualty rate of around 50%. This combination of a larger infantry proportion and a higher casualty rate contributed to the overall casualty rate of **Leibnizâ€™s **army surpassing that of **Newtonâ€™s.**

Lets put the Mathematics going behind in front ofÂ you.

From the graphs, the following observations are very straightforward:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/1*0VpbEryqjHZxEyLQevkQqQ.png)
And you see, the mathematical results are consistent with the [figure 2](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a5e9980b-b348-4fae-985c-fd65bae891a2)Â .

**If data can be partitioned in such a way that a single Simpsonâ€™s reversal emerges, then, logically, it seems inevitable that this reversal will continue as the data is divided evenÂ further.**This very phenomenon is vividly illustrated in Figure 3, where the casualty rates of four distinct military units are laid bare: **Infantry I **(the swordsmen of the first battalion),** Infantry II** (the archers of the second battalion), **Cavalry I** (the nimble, lightly armored cavalry), and **Cavalry II** (the mighty, heavily armored cavalry). With this partitioning, the data splits into four subsets, each telling its own tale. In every single one, **Leibnizâ€™s** battalion suffers greater casualties than **Newtonâ€™sâ€Š**â€”â€Šat least, thatâ€™s what the numbersÂ suggest.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/977/0*4GQfD0T0SMLUF8uY)
Figure 3Yet, as we zoom out and aggregate the data to the level of regiments, the tides begin to shift, and we encounter Figure 1. Here, a stunning reversal occursâ€Šâ€”**â€ŠLeibnizâ€™s** army now appears to have outperformed **Newtonâ€™s!** But the twists do not end there. As we continue to aggregate the data, adding more layers, the final conclusion arrives, and once again, itâ€™s **Newtonâ€™s** army that emerges victorious considering the overall casualtyÂ rate.

**Simpsonâ€™s paradox* says however that this can occur; it is possible for any relation between two variables to be reversed in every component subpopulation***This chain of reversals begs the ultimate question: **Which army truly proved superior?**

I now present you with even **more detailed demographics** of both armies and leave it to you to verify the trend reversal weâ€™ve just witnessed.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/977/0*bq8DWw73EqY-dbSJ)

![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/977/0*0VLPV0qjapWrp6uM)
Do you want to hear one moreÂ truth?

**Newton **and **Leibniz **never participated in any actual wars ğŸ˜œÂ . While their intellectual battle over the discovery of calculus is legendary, they never fought on a physical battlefield. This fact serves as a powerful reminder to snap us out of the hypothetical world weâ€™ve been exploring.

## Time to beÂ serious
Itâ€™s time to set aside our imaginative scenarios and consider the true implications of Simpsonâ€™s Paradox. You might be wondering: **How does Simpsonâ€™s Paradox manifest itself in the realÂ world?**

It turns out, this paradox isnâ€™t just a theoretical quirkâ€Šâ€”â€Šit appears in practical situations more often than you might think. Even during the **COVID-19 pandemic**, Simpsonâ€™s Paradox emerged: when comparing Case Fatality Rates (CFR) between China and Italy, Italy initially seemed to have a higher survival rate, but when the data was split by age group, the conclusion flipped.

For now, letâ€™s focus on one of the most well-known examplesâ€Šâ€”â€Ša study comparing two approaches for treating kidneyÂ stones.

A study by statistician **Steven A. Julious** and senior statistical programmer **Mark A. Mullee** compares two kidney stone treatments: one cutting-edge and minimally invasive, the other a reliable, long-standing method. The success rates, sorted by stone size, suggest a **clearÂ winner**.

**But is there more to consider?**


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/483/0*SR1zzEwi0yB7C2-7)
Reference:

Steven A. Julious and Mark A. Mullee (3 December 1994). *Confounding and Simpsonâ€™s paradox*. BMJ, 309(6967): 1480â€“1481. doi: [10.1136/bmj.309.6967.1480](https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.309.6967.1480). PMC: [2541623](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2541623). PMID:Â [7804052](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7804052/).

## Unraveling the Mystery: The Simpsonâ€™s Paradox atÂ Work
Letâ€™s break this down step by step. At first glance, the data seems pretty straightforward. When you look at the treatments for small and large stones separately, the outcome is clearâ€Šâ€”â€Š**treatment A** consistently outperforms treatment B for both small and large stones. So far, so good, right? Treatment A is the obvious winner in eachÂ case.

But hereâ€™s where things take an unexpected turn: when you combine the data for both small and large stones together, suddenly **treatment B **looks like the better treatment overall.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/630/0*ekTSlZa9K_uP0qGn)
**This seeming contradiction is rooted in the distribution of theÂ data.**

Hereâ€™s what happened:

More patients with **small stones**, (which are generally easier to treat) were assigned **treatment B**. At the same time, a larger proportion of patients with **large stones,** (which are much harder to treat successfully) were assigned **treatment A**. **The size of the kidney stone, it turns out, has a much greater impact on treatment success than the choice of treatment itself.** Smaller stones have a much higher chance of success, regardless of which treatment isÂ used.

When we combine the groups, it creates an illusion that treatment B is more effective because more patients with small stones received it, and those patients had higher success rates. **But if the distribution of patients between the two treatments had been more balanced, this paradox would not have appeared.**

This is exactly why you canâ€™t always trust the overall numbers without considering how the data is divided. **Without factoring in the size of the kidney stone, you might draw the wrong conclusions.**

**This lesson extends beyond kidney stone treatments**â€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s a reminder that data can be misleading if not carefully interpreted. The numbers may seem clear at first, but they can hide deeper truths. Simpsonâ€™s Paradox teaches us to question assumptions and dig deeper before drawing conclusions.

[**Do still you believe the statistical phenomenon described above should be considered aÂ paradox?**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simpson's_paradox#Criticism)

Although criticized, Simpsonâ€™s paradox remains a fascinating and frequently explored topic in statistics and data analysis. Its ongoing study across diverse disciplines highlights the importance of nuanced statistical methods and the dangers of oversimplifying data interpretations.

title: The Drunkardâ€™s Walk and Absorbing Markov Chains
author: Sruthi Subramanian
content:
**Have you heard of the Drunkardâ€™s Walk?**

Before we dive into the technicalities of Markov Chains in this article (part 2 of our Markov Chain series!) letâ€™s first visit a classic problem, which is solved by Markov Chainsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe Drunkardâ€™s Walk. By the end of this article, you would know what the problem is, and how we can use Markov Chains to solveÂ it.

The set up is as givenÂ below:

There are 4 blocks, with 5 corners, say 1,2,3,4 and 5. A drunkard starts at a given corner. His home is at 1, and there is a bar at 5. If he is at 1 or 5, he stays there, but if he is at 2,3 or 4, then with equal probability, he may go to the left or to the right. Hence the cornersâ€Šâ€”â€Š1,2,3,4 and 5 are the states the drunkard can beÂ at.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/1*JLOUcZwjezqrbhxHcYh4Vw.jpeg)
First let us askÂ -

Given a starting state, what is the probability that the drunkard reaches 1 or 5 in a given number of steps(Q0)? Will the drunkard always reach one of these states(Q1)?

Before we dive into this and many other interesting questions, let us revisit what a Markov Chain is and look at what an absorbing Markov ChainÂ is.

**Markov Chains and absorbing MarkovÂ Chains**

As we saw in the previous article, a Markov chain has, â€˜nâ€™ many states, which are denoted by s_i (where i goes from 1 to n), and a Transition Matrix, P, which denotes the probabilities of going from one state to the other, i.e. each element of P, p_ij, represents the probability of going from state s_i to state s_j in oneÂ step.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/0*xgsxEKNl4Cetl7eW)
From the given definitions, it can be obtained that the (ij)th element of the matrix P^n, is the probability of reaching the state, s_j, in n many steps, starting at the state, s_i. (Does this answer our first question about the Drunkardâ€™s walk?â€Šâ€”â€ŠQ0)

In Drunkardâ€™s walk, the states are 1,2,3,4 and 5, and it is not possible to leave 1, and 5. Such states are called absorbing states. *An absorbing Markov Chain is a special kind of Markov Chain, which has at least one absorbing state, such that that state can be reached from any other state*. The Markov Chain we get from the Drunkardâ€™s walk set up, is an absorbing MarkovÂ Chain.

In an absorbing Markov Chain, there are two kinds ofÂ states:

*Absorbing States*: from which it is impossible toÂ leave*Transient States*: the states which are not absorbingHere 1 and 5 are absorbing states and 2,3 and 4 are transient states. Since it is impossible to leave states 1 and 5, and if the man is at 2,3 or 4, there is equal probability to go left or right, we obtain the Transition Matrix for the Drunkardâ€™s walk asÂ follows:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1000/0*ECh_4t45oZ9R7eex)
**The canonical form of the Transition matrix:**

Let the number of transient states be t and the number of absorbing states be r. For any Absorbing Markov Chain, the states can be rearranged, such that the Transient states come first and the Absorbing states laterâ€Šâ€”â€Što obtain the Transition Matrix in theÂ form:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1000/0*IdLzp48X_rxGDiwv)
where I is the (r x r) identity matrix, R is a (t x r) matrix, Q is a (t x t) matrix, and 0 is the (r x t) zero matrix. This is known as the canonical form of the transition matrix, and the canonical form of the transition matrix for the Drunkardâ€™s WalkÂ is:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1000/0*p4mU4QB609fP9NBx)
*Why are we looking at this form of the transition matrix? How does it helpÂ us?*

Observe that when we write the transition matrix, P, in such a form, we get a very neat representation for P^n in terms of Q,R,I and 0. I encourage you to try it out on your own and find this form for yourself.

Additionally, the canonical form of the transition matrix proves useful in solving some problems concerning the Absorbing Markov Chain, which we will see in the nextÂ section!

**What are the key questions we have for an Absorbing MarkovÂ Chain?**

There are mainly 4 questions that we can ask for a given Absorbing MarkovÂ Chain:

Q1) The Probability of Absorption

irrespective of which state we start in, will we always end up in an absorbing state? What do youÂ think?A simple argument to show that *Q^n approaches 0* will show us that whichever state we start at, we will always reach an absorbing state.Q2) Since, the answer to the above problem is yes, the next question that comes to mind is what is the expected number of times we will be in a given state, given a starting state, up till absorption. (note that we count the initial state ifÂ i=j)

This is a question of expectation. Suppose we are trying to find the number of times that we will be in state s_j, given that we are starting atÂ s_i.If s_i or s_j is an absorbing state, then this problem is trivial. Hence let us assume that both of the states are transient states.Observe that the required number will be the sum of the (ij)th element of I, Q, QÂ², QÂ³, and so on, giving us an infiniteÂ sum.We can find the value of this expression, by finding the sum, I+Q+QÂ²+QÂ³+â€¦, which happens to be (I-Q)^(-1).For further reference, let us call this matrix asÂ N.

Q3) We can also ask the question of timeâ€Šâ€”â€Šhow long does it take before reaching an absorbing state (on average)?

Once we have answered the question of how many times we will be in a given state, finding out the time it takes before absorption, becomes a fairly straightforward problem toÂ answer.We simply have to add the expected number of times we will be in each state(we know this from Q2), over s_j, fixing s_iâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat will give us the totalÂ time.Q4) Last but not the least, we ask the probability of being absorbed in each of the absorbing states.

Suppose we start at the transient state, s_i. The probability of being absorbed in the absorbing state, s_j, is the probability that we reach s_j at any point in time, as once we reach there, we will never leave thatÂ state.The number of times we will be in any given state, s_k is N_ik and the probability of being absorbed into s_j, given we are at s_k is R_kj. To get the total probability of absorption in s_j, we need to add N_ik * R_kj over all the possible s_kâ€™s. Hence we can find this probability from the matrix,Â B=NR.(Do observe that the solutions to both 3 and 4, and hence all of the problems, can be written in a matrix form, using N,R, andÂ Q)

I encourage you to use these approaches to answer these problems for the example of the Drunkardâ€™s Walk!

title: Introduction to Markov Chains: An Intersection of Probability and Linear Algebra
author: Sruthi Subramanian
content:
**What will the weather be tomorrow?**

Whether it rains or not is a concern a lot of us have in our everyday life. A heavy rain can change how the rest of our day goes. Hence weather prediction and knowing how likely it is to rain is something that we all are interested in, and a lot of times, depend on to plan our schedules! Let us now dive into a simple probability problem that revolves aroundÂ this.

If you knew the probabilities of the weather being Rainy, Nice or Snowy tomorrow(or one day later), given the weather today(either Rainy, Nice or Snowy), how would you go about finding out the probability of it being Rainy the day after tomorrow, given that it is Nice today(or if it is Snowy or RainyÂ today)?

Let our exampleâ€™s probabilities be asÂ follows:

The probability that it is** Rainy** tomorrow, given that it is **Rainy** today =Â 0.5

The probability that it is **Nice** tomorrow, given that it is **Rainy** today =Â 0.25

The probability that it is **Snowy** tomorrow, given that it is** Rainy** today =Â 0.25

The probability that it is **Rainy** tomorrow, given that it is** Nice **today =Â 0.5

The probability that it is **Nice** tomorrow, given that it is** Nice** today =Â 0

The probability that it is **Snowy** tomorrow, given that it is** Nice** today =Â 0.5

The probability that it is** Rainy** tomorrow, given that it is **Snowy** today =Â 0.25

The probability that it is **Nice** tomorrow, given that it is **Snowy** today =Â 0.25

The probability that it is **Snowy** tomorrow, given that it is **Snowy** today =Â 0.5

Given todayâ€™s weather (say Rainy), observe that the sum of the probabilities of it being Rainy, Nice and Snowy tomorrow is 1 (0.5+0.25+0.25). Why must this be theÂ case?

(Note that we assume that these probabilities donâ€™t change from day to day, and remain same for any two consecutive days)

Now the next question that arises is, given todayâ€™s weather, what are the probabilities for it to be Rainy/Nice/Snowy two days later? Or three days later? Or to generalize this problem, how about **n **daysÂ later?

First let us look at the specific problem: **What is the probability that it is Rainy two days later, given that it is NiceÂ today?**

Using the basic concepts of probability, we can approach this problem asÂ follows.

There are three possible cases that ariseÂ here:

It is Rainy tomorrow and Rainy two days later, given that it is niceÂ todayFor which the probability is

P(Rainy tomorrow|Nice today) * P(Rainy day after tomorrow|Rainy tomorrow)

= P(Rainy tomorrow|Nice today) * P(Rainy tomorrow|Rainy today)

= 0.5*0.5 =Â 0.25

It is Nice tomorrow and Rainy two days later, given that it is niceÂ todayFor which the probability is

P(Nice tomorrow|Nice today) * P(Rainy day after tomorrow|Nice tomorrow)

= 0*0.5 =Â 0

It is Snowy tomorrow and Rainy two days later, given that it is niceÂ todayFor which the probability is

P(Snowy tomorrow|Nice today) * P(Rainy day after tomorrow|Snowy tomorrow)

= 0.5*0.25 =Â 0.125

Hence the probability that it is Rainy the day after tomorrow given that it is nice today, is the sum of these three probabilities, which isÂ 0.375.

Now this seems like a fairly good method to use to find the probability with a day gap. What if we want to find the probability for 4 days later? Taking cases will become a very tedious and time-consuming process, and could also be very confusing. Do observe that while this is likely to be taxing for a human, this is the kind of problem that a computer would do veryÂ well!

Now, using a matrix approach to solve this problem, will allow us to keep track of all the probability values and take care of all these cases in a much more organized manner. This is where the idea of Markov Chains comesÂ in!

**How can we solve this problem with matrices?**

Let us try to represent the given probabilities in a matrix form. Let the (ij)th element of the matrix represent the probability that it is in the state (**s**_j) tomorrow given that it is in the state (**s**_i)Â today.

Note that the states, in this case are the possible weathers it canÂ be:

s_1 = R (Rainy). s_2 = N (Nice). s_3 = SÂ (Snowy).

The row of the element represents the weather today, and the column represents the weather tomorrow(or one day later), for which we are looking at the probability.

Constructing such a matrix, weÂ get:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/193/0*NWHj4FnIsIoMnFc-)
Let this matrix be P. If we take P^2, weÂ have:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/202/0*TVrUHqD31-jRTwT4)
Remember that our problem was to find the probability that it is Rainy two days later, given that it is NiceÂ today.

Observe that the element in the second row, representing that it is Nice today, and the first column, representing that it is Rainy (two days later?), is 0.375, which is the same that we calculated previously, by takingÂ cases.

How does this valueÂ come?

From matrix multiplication, we know that we calculate the corresponding element of the matrix, P^2Â , by taking the inner product of the second row of P with the first column of P, whichÂ is:(0.5*0.5 + 0*0.5 + 0.5*0.25) =Â 0.375

See that the first term represents the probability such that the intermediate day is Rainy, while the next two terms do the same for Nice andÂ Snowy.Writing this out, and taking all the possible cases, we can show that, in general, the (ij)th element of P^2 represents the probability that the weather two days later(or the day after tomorrow) is s_j, given that it is s_iÂ today.**What is a MarkovÂ Chain?**

The sequence of the matrices P^n (n>0) is called a Markov Chain. The Matrix, P, is called the Transition matrix. In a general Markov Chain, the states can be anything, and we can have any number of states. (Do observe that as the number of states increases, the computation for finding the powers of the matrix P, becomes more complicated).

Let our Markov Chain have **n **many states. Then the transition matrix, will be a (n x n) matrix, where the (ij)th element, represents the probability of the state s_j occurring tomorrow(or one day later) given that s_i is todayâ€™s state. If the transition matrix is P, then in P^n, the (ij)th element represents the same probability for the n daysÂ later.

There are various types of Markov Chains, including Absorbing Markov Chains, and Regular Markov Chains, and they have various interesting properties. Those are some interesting things to look forward to in the upcoming articles! Do stay tunedÂ :)

title: Solving the Rubikâ€™s cube using group theory
author: Sruthi Subramanian
content:
Do you remember the time when everyone was so obsessed with solving the cube? We used to have numerous competitions to see who could do it fastest, and being able to solve it swiftly, earned you a little extra respect from all your friends (who didnâ€™t know theÂ trick).

All the cube solvers would know that we generally follow an algorithm to solve the cube. We have a list of possible states of the cube, and then we choose an algorithm to follow, based on which state it is in. (As you probably have figured by now, I too once was mesmerized by that colorfulÂ puzzle.)

In this article, we will be looking into why this works mathematically.

What is used here is something called group theory. Let us look into what group theory actually is, and how it can be used hereÂ :)

**So what is aÂ Group?**

Let us first look at some examples before we go into the definition of a group. Mathematicians came up with groups with the aim to classify symmetries. These could be for any shape, 2-D or 3-D or even more! The actions that maintained the shape were all put into a structure, we call aÂ group.

Let us understand one specific such group, called a dihedralÂ group.Consider a square. Observe that the set of rotations by 90Â°, 180Â°, 270Â° and 360Â°, along with reflection about its axis of symmetry, does not change the orientation of the square. Through these operations, we can generate 8 squares, as given below. These together form a group which is commonly known as the dihedral group (Dn), withÂ n=4.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/663/0*mL0WUZePi4DpTc0c)
We can have similar groups for other regular polygons like triangles or pentagons.

Let us now try to arrange 3 distinct objects in a specific order. We can see that there are a total of 6 ways to arrangeÂ them.
![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/970/0*NwAE9YySQlqCt5Cu)
Together these permutations form a group. Each element of the group is a bijective function from {1,2,3} toÂ {1,2,3}

Similarly we have groups for any number of distinct objects, and the group for n objects is called Sn. These groups are of special significance as they contain all the other finite groups in them. Also, using these groups we can show that while we have expressions for the solutions of polynomial equations up to order 4, we do not have such an expression for a fifth order polynomial. Feel free to check out the youtube video in the references for a better understanding!

Now let us see how a group is defined. A group is simply a set, with a binary operation(â‹…). The binary operation along with the set, follows some properties, like closure(if a and b are in the group, then aâ‹…b is also in the group) and associativity(for a,b,c, elements in the group, aâ‹…(bâ‹…c)=(aâ‹…b)â‹…c). Additionally, the group has an identity, which when operated with any element, gives back that element. Also, every element has an inverse, which when it is operated with, we get the identity. Note that in a group, the identity element is unique, and for each element there is a uniqueÂ inverse.Another example of a group is all the integers, with + as the operation. Note that here the identity will be 0, and the inverse for any element, x, will be -x. Groups are abstract, and they are used in mathematics to study various other things, as they have a particular structure, which we can use to characterize them.**How are we using groupsÂ here?**

In the case of solving a Rubikâ€™s cube, we create a group, containing the possible moves as the elements. The group would contain R(right), L(left), U(up), D(down), F(front) and B(back), which tell us which face to rotate. We will fix the direction of rotation, say as clockwise. Then using the inverses of these elements, we can represent anti-clockwise rotation. Each of these elements changes the position of some of the cubicles on the cube. We can easily observe which cubicles go where for each of the operations.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1024/0*dvGLR1SH-xKVccNF)
In this group, our binary operation will be composition. So, what we do is we compose multiple moves in a particular order. And since we know what each move does to the cubicles, using that, we can deduce where each cubicle goes after the composition of some elements.

Now, usually, the cube is solved layer by layer, which means that first we solve it such that all the colors in one layer are in sync, then we do the same thing for the second layer, then we finally solve the third layer and we areÂ done.

One challenge we face is that when we decide which elements in which order we want to compose for the first layer, it is fairly easy, because we need to worry about only where those 9 cubicles move. The other cubicles will also change positions in the process, but we donâ€™t really care about them when we are solving for the firstÂ layer.

This becomes a problem for the subsequent layers, because we need to ensure that the first layer stays intact when we are solving the second layer, and the first and second layers should stay intact when we are solving the third layer. This puts extra constraints on our algorithm, i.e., on the elements we compose to achieve the desired output. Hence as we decide which movements to do when solving a layer, we need to keep in mind how all the cubicles are moving. The group theory abstraction of the moves in a cube helps us to do that efficiently.

If you are interested in details of how the group looks and how the elements look, or if you want to see how simple (or complicated) the algorithm really is, I would encourage you to check out the paper given in the references, by Courtney Cooke, Rhode IslandÂ College!

title: Fibonacci Numbers and Some of its Applications
author: Sruthi Subramanian
content:
**What is the Fibonacci Sequence?**The Fibonacci Sequence, is defined as the follows: F(n) + F(nâˆ’1) = F(n+1) for n â‰¥ 1, and F(0) = 0, F(1) = 1, where F(n) represents the nth term of the sequence. It can also be written as 0,1,1,2,3,5,8,13,21,â€¦. It was inspired by the Rabbit Problem, which is discussed in SectionÂ 4.

**2. The Fibonacci Bamboozlement**

Let us first look into a problem which we can possibly solve using the properties of the Fibonacci sequence. Consider a square of length 8. Split that into triangle and trapezoids as shown in figureÂ (a).


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/348/1*PLEOcCYPQ6zAxJwYi_PqDg.png)
If we rearrange these pieces, we can form a rectangle of length, 13 and breadth,Â 5.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/390/1*-jzgVy4fzEGh40q5VrxYcA.png)
Now compare the areas of these two quadrilaterals. Figure (a) has an area of 64 units, while figure (b) has an area of 65 units. Did we just create one unit of area? Read on to findÂ out!

**3. Some properties of theÂ sequence**

There are many interesting properties of this sequence, some of which we will exploreÂ below:

3.1. The GoldenÂ Ratio

The ratio between two consecutive numbers in the sequence, F(n+1)/F(n), approaches a constant value as n approaches infinity. This value is called the Golden Ratio and its value is around 1.618 (it is exactly (âˆš5 +1)/2). You are encouraged to put the values of the terms of the sequence into Excel and calculate and see for yourself that the ratio of consecutive terms does indeed converge to this value as n becomesÂ larger.

3.2. Binetâ€™sÂ Formula

What should we do if we want to find an element of the sequence? One approach would be to start from F(0) = 0 and F(1) = 1 and use the recursive relation to find further elements. This would work for a small value of n, say 5, for which we need to further calculate only F(2), F(3), F(4) and F(5). But this method is not feasible for larger numbers, say for n=100 or 1000. This is where Binetâ€™s Formula comes in. It is a formula through which we can directly find any element of the Fibonacci Sequence, without having to follow the iterative process that will follow from the recursive formula in the definition of the sequence.

The Binet Formula is given asÂ follows:

F(n) = (Î¦^nâˆ’Ï•^n)/âˆš5

where (âˆš5+1)/2 = Î¦, (1âˆ’ âˆš5)/2 = âˆ’Ï•, Î¦ is the Golden Ratio and Ï• is the conjugate of the GoldenÂ Ratio.

3.3. Cassiniâ€™s Identity

The Cassiniâ€™s Identity gives a relation between 3 consecutive Fibonacci numbers. It is stated asÂ follows:

F(n+1)F(nâˆ’1) âˆ’ F(n)Â² =Â (-1)^n

It can be derived by defining a Q matrix, finding the general form for its nth power, and applying properties of determinants


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/218/1*LEzXiRI-CIIMhPGuakMZ0A.png)
3.4. The Fibonacci Spiral

The Fibonacci Spiral is a geometric representation of the sequence, constructed using the following property of the Fibonacci sequence (which can be proved by Mathematical Induction):

F(1)Â²+F(2)Â²+â€¦+F(n)Â² = F(n)F(n+1)

We start with two tiles of area 1, placed adjacent to each other. From the formula, we know that the length of this rectangle formed will be F(n+1). So we add a square of side F(n+1) to the figure, with the side attached to the length of our initial rectangle. Now the total figure is another rectangle with length F(n+2). We will now add a square of length F(n+2) and continue this process. By drawing a spiral through the corners of these tiles, we get the Fibonacci spiral:


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/401/1*n-3XwvvsKGYbzeLpnKRXgQ.png)
**4. RabbitÂ Problem**

4.1. Problem

A man put a male-female pair of newly born rabbits in a field. It is given that Rabbits take one month to mature, before mating. One month after mating, the female rabbit gives birth to a male female pair, and then they mate again. No rabbits die. How many pairs of rabbits are there after oneÂ year?

4.2. Solution

Consider the number of pairs of juvenile rabbits, adult rabbits, and total rabbits in each month. Note that: The number of pairs of juvenile rabbits in each month will be the number of pairs of adult rabbits in the previous month, and the number of pairs of adult rabbits in a given month will be the sum of the number of pairs of adult rabbits and juvenile rabbits of the previous month. Now we are given that in the first month, we have 1 pair of juvenile rabbits and 0 pairs of adult rabbits. Using these conditions, we can calculate the number of pairs after oneÂ year.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/887/1*L8z3gbvxVpVJ01GB3TmhQw.png)
Observe that the sequence of the number of rabbit pairs in each month gives us the Fibonacci sequence.

**5. Staircase Problem**

In how many ways can one climb a staircase of n steps taking either one or two steps at a time? Climbing a staircase of n stairs is the same as taking one step and then climbing a staircase of (n-1) stairs or taking two steps and then climbing a staircase of (n-2) stairs. From here, the problem can be directly connected to the Fibonacci sequence, as this problem too follows the same rule, F(n)=F(nâˆ’1) + F(nâˆ’2). The only difference will be in the initial condition, here we can climb a staircase of one step in 1 way, while we can climb a staircase of 2 steps, in 2 ways(either take two steps or take one step twice). So the ways we can climb a staircase with n steps will beÂ F(n+1).

**6. Neighbour Swapping**

6.1. Problem

Consider a string of the first n natural numbers. 12345..n Allow each number in the string to either stay fixed or change places with one of its neighbours. How many different strings can beÂ formed?

6.2. Solution

Try this in a similar manner as the staircase problem. The number of such strings isÂ F(n+1).

**7. Fibonacci inÂ Nature**

The number of petals on a flower is generally a Fibonacci Number. Fibonacci numbers are also seen in the arrangement of leaves on plants. The Fibonacci spiral is seen in various fruits and vegetables including pineapples, bananas and cauliflowers. The spiral is also seen in pine cones and in some flowers. We can observe it even in humans, for example, the ratio of the length of our forearm, to our palm length is close to the golden ratio. Check it out for yourself!

**8. Reality of the Fibonacci Bamboozlement**

Cassiniâ€™s identity can be used to understand this problem. Observe that in our problem (refer Section 2), the side lengths which were 5, 8 and 13, are consecutive Fibonacci Numbers. From Cassiniâ€™s identity, we can understand that the difference between such cases of quadrilaterals will be 1. If k is taken as even, then the rectangle will have an area that is 1 unit more than theÂ square.


![Image](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/658/1*NL0XhPMgfr8lE2QcqpIYIg.png)
The slopes of the 2 hypotenuses vary. As we increase n, the slopes(which are actually the ratio of the consecutive Fibonacci numbers) converge to the same value, i.e. the golden ratio. As the values of the slopes become similar, the gap appears lessÂ obvious.
